item.title: Setting up Keras/Tensorflow in RStudio
item.description: I’ve recently grown more interested in understanding deep learning (DL) and so I purchased Deep Learning in R from Manning Books along with its digital course taught by @Rick_Scavetta. It’s been very interesting and so naturally I was excited to try my hand at the “Hello, World!” of DL and play with the infamous MNIST dataset.

item.title: Comparing Majors
item.description: Background Footgolf is a new sport and there are a lot of things that are still being figured out. One such item is that courses arenâ€™t rated like they are in golf. Rating requires a whole new level of experience that the sport just doesnâ€™t have a whole lot of yet. Rating a course requires taking into account many different variables like slope, distance, obstacles, etc. You can read about it here from the PGA website.

item.title: Capital Cup
item.description: Another Major, another analysisâ€¦ This time I didnâ€™t have the pleasure of being there, but it was fun to keep up from afar. Iâ€™ve pulled data and calculated the course statistics for the tournament. Overall Stats Some interesting patterns emerge when calculating all the scores across all rounds. Holes 3, 7, 12, and 14 were the most difficult. Three of them were par 3â€™s and one par 4.

item.title: US Open
item.description: Introduction The American FootGolf League (AFGL) and River Ridge Golf Course hosted the 2018 U.S. Open in Oxnard, CA on April 26th - 29th. The tournament saw players attend from all over the world for the first major of the FIFG World Tour. The course was very difficult as it was both long (~3600 yds), sloped, fast, and occassionally windy. I played in the tournament myself, albeit not well, and anecdotally found that certain holes were more troublesome than others, especially depending on time of day (ex, windy).

item.title: About
item.description: Social Media linkedin twitter github Fun facts I don’t like coffee (my wife LOVES IT though) I have literally herded cats I dj ðŸ˜Ž I LOVE learning and exploring new concepts and ideas and bringing them to life. Origin story I pretty much knew I wanted to be a scientist since the age of 5. The declaration came while in Yosemite. My Mom and her best friend were getting ready for a wedding.
